Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2008 05:39PM mrschilicook wrote: Well, I've joined the club of frightened but determined to win folks on this thread.  Chemo scares the bejeezes out of me, but the alternatives are worse.  So I talked to my doctor and had him put me on Xanax (not something I would normally even consider).  It smoothed the feeling of panic and I plan to stay on it through out my treatment (begins Oct 30th) if I'm allowed.  I try to remember all of the good things that have come into my life again.. old friends, my mom, new friends.  There have actually been some postive things on the personal relationship front out of this.  I'm trying my damndest to be positive, but it's hard sometimes.  So we're there with you and you will be successful in getting thru this.  In a year you'll look back and know you were stronger than you think you are now.
Posts.Title: Chemo is scaring me so badly. Please help me. Mocity nanclee

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2009 01:38PM mrschilicook wrote: Get the second opinion if it would make YOU feel better.  I did the same, and both opinions were the same.  However, know that chemo is different for everyone.  It's not as bad as the movies would have you believe.  Everyone's reaction is different.  I had T & C.  The first session was okay although I drank a gallon of water by the time I got home.  I was wiped out for about 7 days with no appetite, tired, listless. There was no sickness, quesiness, etc...they give you enough pills for an ox to take care of that side effect now.  On day 8 my appetite began to return and by 12 days after chemo I was pretty much back to normal.  The second was about the same but my recovery was fewer days.  My third sesson was wierd in that I had a reaction to the chemicals which caused them to pause, IV me with steroids, histamines, etc. and then resume.  The after effects were minor from the chemo.   Due to another issue, the 3rd session ended up being my last.  So be strong, be informed, have friends and family around you and know it may not be nearly as bad as your imagining.

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2009 02:23PM mrschilicook wrote: Well, just know that if the tumor had been large enough they would have recommended radiation to attempt to reduce it's size before the surgery.  It sounds like you caught it early and it wasn't necessary. It was two months from the time I had surgery to the time I had chemo.  Use those months to rest and relax as much as possible.  My cancer team said that there was very little chance that anything would happen during that time period.  I also had an anxiety attack.  My husband had died in May and I experienced my first (and only) anxiety attack.  When they diagnosed me with cancer in August 2008 I felt it coming on again.  The doctor gave me a prescription for Xanax which is an anti-anxiety drug without the potential side effects of Abiean CR (sp?).  It kept me level and somewhat sane thru the whole 3 months. As a matter of fact I'm still on it but down to 1 per day as I get thru a few other things. Also, I think your statistics may be old.  The cancer survival rate with chemo is much higher than you indicated.  If they gave you that weird chart like they did me, it is poorly explained and skewed. BTW: I also had triple neg. cancer.  Seems that it's the one that almost ALWAYS gets the nod with chemo.  It's done "just in case" something escaped into your system.  If your nodes were clear (and it sounds like they were), then the time your taking to heal is a good thing.  I had a lumpectomy due to the size and location (.67 mm and on the lower left breast very near the breast bone).  It was what the cancer team recommended and what my surgeon said he would recommend for his wife or mother.  So that was the route I took.

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2009 04:30PM mrschilicook wrote: I know this is an old post, but I thought I would chime in anyway.  I had my last chemo Dec. 11th 2008 and by the end of Jan. 2009 I had a good head of peach fuzz.  Have to admit though, I had actually grown fond of being bald.  No shampoo, no conditioner, no bad hair days.  Just slap on a wig and some makeup or a "chemo cap" and some just earrings and your off.  I never knew my hair added so much time to my daily routine.   My hair dresser said to come in when the hair was about 1 inch long (it's coming in very uneven) so she could trim up the ends so it wasn't quite so fuzzy/curly as it grew out.  But it sure is grey.  I always told my husband, when he was alive, that if I ever quit dying my hair I would shave it rather than let it grow out thru that ugly stage.  Maybe this is the time (or maybe not).

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2008 08:26PM mrschilicook wrote: Hi.  My name is Paulette and I'm 62.  My husband and I retired 5 years ago to travel.  Last year we moved to Saddlebrooke MO (near Branson) from California.  In May my husband died suddenly (and unexpectedly) of heart arrest.  I have no children but I do have an 18 month old black lab mix named Lucy. In August I was diagnosed with BC.  I had a partial masectomy Sept. 2nd, followed by mammosite radiation ending on October 22nd.  I go in on Monday        Oct. 20th to have a port installed and begin 4 rounds, 21 days apart, of the two compound chemo (T/C?) on October 30th.   Needless to say, this has been a very tough year.    I'm actually okay with losing my hair (at least I am so far), I'm much more concerned about the long term affects to my brain, liver, heart, etc.  And the fact that cancer has, in some ways, postponed my grief.  I dread it coming back when this is over.  I'm finding this whole thing a bit barbaric that the only cure we have for wifes/mothers/daughters is to poison them.  But I'll do what I need to do and be stronger at the end of it for it.  We all will.

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2009 11:59AM mrschilicook wrote: Well, congrats and sorry for the late response.  Somehow I found that I needed to leave all things "medical" for a few months while I gathered my life back up.  I'm now heading towards that 1 year mark since I was diagnosed.  I can't wait to get the power port removed so that all traces of 2008 are over.  Overall I have to admit that the experience was life changing, but not so dramatic as I had worried imagined.  And much of those changes are postive...I have reconnected with some old friends, strengthened my ties with close friends, and healed my shaky relationship with my mom.  While becoming a widow was the worst part of 2008 and was the biggest reshaper of my life, the cancer brought friends and family closer than ever before.  So in strange ways, the cancer had a positive side.
